page.title: 06Local History
page.content: In 1925, Sanquhar, then little more than the High Street, had its own cobbler, clog-maker, two tailors, a bakery and an abattoir - none of these establishments are now in evidence. The main employers were two forges, two coal mines, a brickworks, a brewery and agriculture. The town had 4 ministers, one doctor and one policeman. Gas was the source of power and the lamplighter, who was also the town crier, rang the Tolbooth bells twice daily - when the shops were to open and close. Horse drawn transport was dominant - milk, groceries and coal being delivered by cart. A semi professional football team had its stadium on the outskirts of the town. Youth organisations- Guides, Brownies, Cubs and Scouts - were well supported; and for adults the town offered golf, green bowling and quoits.
